We do not know who murdered former Russian spy Alexander Litvinenko with an obscure radioactive isotope in London this fall.

Just a couple of weeks ago, former Russian Prime Minister Yegor Gaidar claimed that he'd been poisoned in Ireland.

However, there does appear to be a pattern of threats and assassinations of critics of Russian President Vladimir Putin that many lay on a shadowy network of former KGB agents.
President Putin himself of course is a former member of the old Soviet Union's Committee on State Security.
After the fall of communism, the KGB was split into two.
